title: King Henry VI, the first part

dialogues.speaker: Bedford
dialogues.line: Hung be the heavens with black, yield day to night! Comets, importing change of times and states, Brandish your crystal tresses in the sky, And with them scourge the bad revolting stars That have consented unto Henry's death: King Henry the Fifth, too famous to live long! England ne'er lost a king of so much worth.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: England ne'er had a king until his time. Virtue he had, deserving to command; His brandish'd sword did blind men with his beams; His arms spread wider than a dragon's wings; His sparkling eyes, replete with wrathful fire, More dazzled and drove back his enemies Than mid-day sun fierce bent against their faces. What should I say? His deeds exceed all speech. He ne'er lift up his hand but conquered.

dialogues.speaker: Exeter
dialogues.line: We mourn in black; why mourn we not in blood? Henry is dead and never shall revive. Upon a wooden coffin we attend, And Death's dishonourable victory We with our stately presence glorify, Like captives bound to a triumphant car. What! Shall we curse the planets of mishap That plotted thus our glory's overthrow? Or shall we think the subtle-witted French Conjurers and sorcerers, that, afraid of him, By magic verses have contriv'd his end?

dialogues.speaker: Winchester
dialogues.line: He was a king bless'd of the King of kings; Unto the French the dreadful judgement-day So dreadful will not be as was his sight. The battles of the Lord of Hosts he fought: The Church's prayers made him so prosperous.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: The Church! Where is it? Had not churchmen pray'd, His thread of life had not so soon decay'd. None do you like but an effeminate prince, Whom like a school-boy you may overawe.

dialogues.speaker: Winchester
dialogues.line: Gloucester, whate'er we like, thou art Protector, And lookest to command the Prince and realm. Thy wife is proud; she holdeth thee in awe More than God or religious churchmen may.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Name not religion, for thou lov'st the flesh, And ne'er throughout the year to church thou go'st, Except it be to pray against thy foes.

dialogues.speaker: Bedford
dialogues.line: Cease, cease these jars, and rest your minds in peace; Let's to the altar; heralds, wait on us. Instead of gold, we'll offer up our arms, Since arms avail not, now that Henry's dead. Posterity, await for wretched years, When at their mothers' moist eyes babes shall suck, Our isle be made a nourish of salt tears, And none but women left to wail the dead. Henry the Fifth, thy ghost I invocate: Prosper this realm, keep it from civil broils, Combat with adverse planets in the heavens. A far more glorious star thy soul will make Than Julius Caesar or bright-

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: My honourable lords, health to you all! Sad tidings bring I to you out of France, Of loss, of slaughter, and discomfiture: Guienne, Champaigne, Rheims, Rouen, Orleans, Paris, Guysors, Poictiers, are all quite lost.

dialogues.speaker: Bedford
dialogues.line: What say'st thou, man, before dead Henry's corse? Speak softly, or the loss of those great towns Will make him burst his lead and rise from death.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Is Paris lost? Is Rouen yielded up? If Henry were recall'd to life again, These news would cause him once more yield the ghost.

dialogues.speaker: Exeter
dialogues.line: How were they lost? What treachery was us'd?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: No treachery, but want of men and money. Amongst the soldiers this is muttered: That here you maintain several factions And whilst a field should be dispatch'd and fought, You are disputing of your generals. One would have lingering wars with little cost; Another would fly swift, but wanteth wings; A third thinks, without expense at all, By guileful fair words peace may be obtain'd. Awake, awake, English nobility! Let not sloth dim your honours new-begot. Cropp'd are the flower-de-luces in your arms; Of England's coat one half is cut away.

dialogues.speaker: Exeter
dialogues.line: Were our tears wanting to this funeral, These tidings would call forth their flowing tides.

dialogues.speaker: Bedford
dialogues.line: Me they concern; Regent I am of France. Give me my steeled coat. I'll fight for France. Away with these disgraceful wailing robes! Wounds will I lend the French instead of eyes, To weep their intermissive miseries.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Lords, view these letters full of bad mischance. France is revolted from the English quite, Except some petty towns of no import. The Dauphin Charles is crowned king in Rheims; The Bastard of Orleans with him is join'd; Reignier, Duke of Anjou, doth take his part; The Duke of Alençon flieth to his side.

dialogues.speaker: Exeter
dialogues.line: The Dauphin crowned king! All fly to him! O, whither shall we fly from this reproach?

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: We will not fly but to our enemies' throats. Bedford, if thou be slack, I'll fight it out.

dialogues.speaker: Bedford
dialogues.line: Gloucester, why doubt'st thou of my forwardness? An army have I muster'd in my thoughts, Wherewith already France is overrun.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: My gracious lords, to add to your laments, Wherewith you now bedew King Henry's hearse, I must inform you of a dismal fight Betwixt the stout Lord Talbot and the French.

dialogues.speaker: Winchester
dialogues.line: What! Wherein Talbot overcame, is't so?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: O no, wherein Lord Talbot was o'erthrown. The circumstance I'll tell you more at large. The tenth of August last this dreadful lord, Retiring from the siege of Orleans, Having full scarce six thousand in his troop, By three and twenty thousand of the French Was round encompassed and set upon. No leisure had he to enrank his men; He wanted pikes to set before his archers; Instead whereof sharp stakes pluck'd out of hedges They pitched in the ground confusedly To keep the horsemen off from breaking in. More than three hours the fight continued; Where valiant Talbot, above human thought, Enacted wonders with his sword and lance. Hundreds he sent to hell, and none durst stand him; Here, there, and everywhere, enrag'd he slew. The French exclaim'd the devil was in arms; All the whole army stood agaz'd on him. His soldiers, spying his undaunted spirit, "A Talbot! a Talbot!" cried out amain, And rush'd into the bowels of the battle. Here had the conquest fully been seal'd up If Sir John Fastolf had not play'd the coward. He, being in the vaward, plac'd behind With purpose to relieve and follow them, Cowardly fled, not having struck one stroke. Hence grew the general wrack and massacre. Enclosed were they with their enemies. A base Walloon, to win the Dauphin's grace, Thrust Talbot with a spear into the back, Whom all France, with their chief assembled strength, Durst not presume to look once in the face.

dialogues.speaker: Bedford
dialogues.line: Is Talbot slain? Then I will slay myself, For living idly here, in pomp and ease, Whilst such a worthy leader, wanting aid, Unto his dastard foemen is betray'd.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: O no, he lives, but is took prisoner, And Lord Scales with him, and Lord Hungerford; Most of the rest slaughter'd or took likewise.

dialogues.speaker: Bedford
dialogues.line: His ransom there is none but I shall pay. I'll hale the Dauphin headlong from his throne; His crown shall be the ransom of my friend; Four of their lords I'll change for one of ours. Farewell, my masters; to my task will I; Bonfires in France forthwith I am to make To keep our great Saint George's feast withal. Ten thousand soldiers with me I will take, Whose bloody deeds shall make all Europe quake.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: So you had need; for Orleans is besieg'd The English army is grown weak and faint; The Earl of Salisbury craveth supply And hardly keeps his men from mutiny, Since they, so few, watch such a multitude.

dialogues.speaker: Exeter
dialogues.line: Remember, lords, your oaths to Henry sworn, Either to quell the Dauphin utterly, Or bring him in obedience to your yoke.

dialogues.speaker: Bedford
dialogues.line: I do remember it, and here take my leave To go about my preparation.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: I'll to the Tower with all the haste I can To view th' artillery and munition; And then I will proclaim young Henry king.

dialogues.speaker: Exeter
dialogues.line: To Eltham will I, where the young King is, Being ordain'd his special governor; And for his safety there I'll best devise.

dialogues.speaker: Winchester
dialogues.line: Each hath his place and function to attend. I am left out; for me nothing remains. But long I will not be Jack out of office. The King from Eltham I intend to steal, And sit at chiefest stern of public weal.

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: Mars his true moving, even as in the heavens So in the earth, to this day is not known. Late did he shine upon the English side; Now we are victors; upon us he smiles. What towns of any moment but we have? At pleasure here we lie near Orleans, Otherwhiles the famish'd English, like pale ghosts, Faintly besiege us one hour in a month. ALENÇON. They want their porridge and their fat bull beeves. Either they must be dieted like mules And have their provender tied to their mouths, Or piteous they will look, like drowned mice.

dialogues.speaker: Reignier
dialogues.line: Let's raise the siege. Why live we idly here? Talbot is taken, whom we wont to fear. Remaineth none but mad-brain'd Salisbury, And he may well in fretting spend his gall; Nor men nor money hath he to make war.

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: Sound, sound alarum! We will rush on them. Now for the honour of the forlorn French! Him I forgive my death that killeth me When he sees me go back one foot or fly. Here alarum; they are beaten back by the English, with great loss. Re-enter Charles, Alençon and Reignier.

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: Who ever saw the like? What men have I! Dogs, cowards, dastards! I would ne'er have fled But that they left me 'midst my enemies.

dialogues.speaker: Reignier
dialogues.line: Salisbury is a desperate homicide; He fighteth as one weary of his life. The other lords, like lions wanting food, Do rush upon us as their hungry prey. ALENÇON. Froissart, a countryman of ours, records, England all Olivers and Rowlands bred During the time Edward the Third did reign. More truly now may this be verified; For none but Samsons and Goliases It sendeth forth to skirmish. One to ten! Lean raw-bon'd rascals! Who would e'er suppose They had such courage and audacity?

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: Let's leave this town; for they are hare-brain'd slaves, And hunger will enforce them to be more eager. Of old I know them; rather with their teeth The walls they'll tear down than forsake the siege.

dialogues.speaker: Reignier
dialogues.line: I think by some odd gimmers or device Their arms are set like clocks, still to strike on; Else ne'er could they hold out so as they do. By my consent, we'll even let them alone. ALENÇON. Be it so.

dialogues.speaker: Bastard
dialogues.line: Where's the Prince Dauphin? I have news for him.

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: Bastard of Orleans, thrice welcome to us.

dialogues.speaker: Bastard
dialogues.line: Methinks your looks are sad, your cheer appall'd. Hath the late overthrow wrought this offence? Be not dismay'd, for succour is at hand. A holy maid hither with me I bring, Which, by a vision sent to her from heaven Ordained is to raise this tedious siege And drive the English forth the bounds of France. The spirit of deep prophecy she hath, Exceeding the nine sibyls of old Rome. What's past and what's to come she can descry. Speak, shall I call her in? Believe my words, For they are certain and unfallible.

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: Go, call her in. But first, to try her skill, Reignier, stand thou as Dauphin in my place; Question her proudly; let thy looks be stern. By this means shall we sound what skill she hath.

dialogues.speaker: Reignier
dialogues.line: Fair maid, is 't thou wilt do these wondrous feats?

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: Reignier is 't thou that thinkest to beguile me? Where is the Dauphin? Come, come from behind; I know thee well, though never seen before. Be not amazed, there's nothing hid from me. In private will I talk with thee apart. Stand back, you lords, and give us leave awhile.

dialogues.speaker: Reignier
dialogues.line: She takes upon her bravely at first dash.

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: Dauphin, I am by birth a shepherd's daughter, My wit untrain'd in any kind of art. Heaven and our Lady gracious hath it pleased To shine on my contemptible estate. Lo, whilst I waited on my tender lambs, And to sun's parching heat display'd my cheeks, God's mother deigned to appear to me, And in a vision full of majesty Will'd me to leave my base vocation And free my country from calamity. Her aid she promised and assured success. In complete glory she reveal'd herself; And, whereas I was black and swart before, With those clear rays which she infused on me That beauty am I blest with which you may see. Ask me what question thou canst possible, And I will answer unpremeditated. My courage try by combat, if thou dar'st, And thou shalt find that I exceed my sex. Resolve on this; thou shalt be fortunate If thou receive me for thy warlike mate.

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: Thou hast astonish'd me with thy high terms. Only this proof I'll of thy valour make: In single combat thou shalt buckle with me, And if thou vanquishest, thy words are true; Otherwise I renounce all confidence.

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: I am prepared. Here is my keen-edg'd sword, Deck'd with five flower-de-luces on each side, The which at Touraine, in Saint Katharine's churchyard, Out of a great deal of old iron I chose forth.

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: Then come, o' God's name; I fear no woman.

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: And while I live, I'll ne'er fly from a man.

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: Stay, stay thy hands; thou art an Amazon, And fightest with the sword of Deborah.

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: Christ's Mother helps me, else I were too weak.

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: Whoe'er helps thee, 'tis thou that must help me. Impatiently I burn with thy desire; My heart and hands thou hast at once subdued. Excellent Pucelle, if thy name be so, Let me thy servant and not sovereign be. 'Tis the French Dauphin sueth to thee thus.

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: I must not yield to any rites of love, For my profession's sacred from above. When I have chased all thy foes from hence, Then will I think upon a recompense.

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: Meantime look gracious on thy prostrate thrall.

dialogues.speaker: Reignier
dialogues.line: My lord, methinks, is very long in talk. ALENÇON. Doubtless he shrives this woman to her smock; Else ne'er could he so long protract his speech.

dialogues.speaker: Reignier
dialogues.line: Shall we disturb him, since he keeps no mean? ALENÇON. He may mean more than we poor men do know. These women are shrewd tempters with their tongues.

dialogues.speaker: Reignier
dialogues.line: My lord, where are you? What devise you on? Shall we give over Orleans, or no?

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: Why, no, I say. Distrustful recreants! Fight till the last gasp; I will be your guard.

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: What she says I'll confirm. We'll fight it out.

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: Assign'd am I to be the English scourge. This night the siege assuredly I'll raise. Expect Saint Martin's summer, halcyon's days, Since I have entered into these wars. Glory is like a circle in the water, Which never ceaseth to enlarge itself Till by broad spreading it disperse to nought. With Henry's death the English circle ends; Dispersed are the glories it included. Now am I like that proud insulting ship Which Caesar and his fortune bare at once.

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: Was Mahomet inspired with a dove? Thou with an eagle art inspired then. Helen, the mother of great Constantine, Nor yet Saint Philip's daughters, were like thee. Bright star of Venus, fall'n down on the earth, How may I reverently worship thee enough? ALENÇON. Leave off delays, and let us raise the siege.

dialogues.speaker: Reignier
dialogues.line: Woman, do what thou canst to save our honours; Drive them from Orleans and be immortalized.

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: Presently we'll try. Come, let's away about it. No prophet will I trust if she prove false.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: I am come to survey the Tower this day. Since Henry's death, I fear, there is conveyance. Where be these warders that they wait not here? Open the gates; 'tis Gloucester that calls.

dialogues.speaker: First Warder
dialogues.line: Who's there that knocks so imperiously?

dialogues.speaker: First Servingman
dialogues.line: It is the noble Duke of Gloucester.

dialogues.speaker: Second Warder
dialogues.line: Whoe'er he be, you may not be let in.

dialogues.speaker: First Servingman
dialogues.line: Villains, answer you so the Lord Protector?

dialogues.speaker: First Warder
dialogues.line: The Lord protect him, so we answer him. We do no otherwise than we are will'd.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Who willed you? Or whose will stands but mine? There's none Protector of the realm but I. Break up the gates, I'll be your warrantize. Shall I be flouted thus by dunghill grooms?

dialogues.speaker: Woodville
dialogues.line: What noise is this? What traitors have we here?

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Lieutenant, is it you whose voice I hear? Open the gates; here's Gloucester that would enter.

dialogues.speaker: Woodville
dialogues.line: Have patience, noble Duke; I may not open; The Cardinal of Winchester forbids. From him I have express commandment That thou nor none of thine shall be let in.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Faint-hearted Woodville, prizest him 'fore me? Arrogant Winchester, that haughty prelate Whom Henry, our late sovereign, ne'er could brook? Thou art no friend to God or to the King. Open the gates, or I'll shut thee out shortly.

dialogues.speaker: Servingmen
dialogues.line: Open the gates unto the Lord Protector, Or we'll burst them open, if that you come not quickly. tawny coats.

dialogues.speaker: Winchester
dialogues.line: How now, ambitious Humphrey! What means this?

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Peel'd priest, dost thou command me to be shut out?

dialogues.speaker: Winchester
dialogues.line: I do, thou most usurping proditor, And not Protector, of the King or realm.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Stand back, thou manifest conspirator, Thou that contrived'st to murder our dead lord; Thou that giv'st whores indulgences to sin: I'll canvass thee in thy broad cardinal's hat, If thou proceed in this thy insolence.

dialogues.speaker: Winchester
dialogues.line: Nay, stand thou back; I will not budge a foot. This be Damascus, be thou cursed Cain, To slay thy brother Abel, if thou wilt.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: I will not slay thee, but I'll drive thee back. Thy scarlet robes, as a child's bearing-cloth, I'll use to carry thee out of this place.

dialogues.speaker: Winchester
dialogues.line: Do what thou dar'st, I beard thee to thy face.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: What, am I dared and bearded to my face? Draw, men, for all this privileged place. Blue coats to tawny coats. Priest, beware your beard; I mean to tug it and to cuff you soundly. Under my feet I'll stamp thy cardinal's hat; In spite of Pope or dignities of church, Here by the cheeks I'll drag thee up and down.

dialogues.speaker: Winchester
dialogues.line: Gloucester, thou wilt answer this before the Pope.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Winchester goose, I cry, "a rope, a rope!" Now beat them hence; why do you let them stay? Thee I'll chase hence, thou wolf in sheep's array. Out, tawny coats! Out, scarlet hypocrite! Here Gloucester's men beat out the Cardinal's men, and enter in the hurly-burly the Mayor of London and his Officers.

dialogues.speaker: Mayor
dialogues.line: Fie, lords, that you, being supreme magistrates, Thus contumeliously should break the peace!

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Peace, Mayor! Thou know'st little of my wrongs. Here's Beaufort, that regards nor God nor king, Hath here distrain'd the Tower to his use.

dialogues.speaker: Winchester
dialogues.line: Here's Gloucester, a foe to citizens, One that still motions war and never peace, O'ercharging your free purses with large fines; That seeks to overthrow religion, Because he is Protector of the realm, And would have armour here out of the Tower, To crown himself king and suppress the Prince.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: I will not answer thee with words, but blows.

dialogues.speaker: Mayor
dialogues.line: Nought rests for me in this tumultuous strife But to make open proclamation. Come, officer, as loud as e'er thou canst, cry.

dialogues.speaker: Officer
dialogues.line: All manner of men assembled here in arms this day against God's peace and the King's, we charge and command you, in his Highness' name, to repair to your several dwelling-places; and not to wear, handle, or use any sword, weapon, or dagger, henceforward, upon pain of death.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Cardinal, I'll be no breaker of the law; But we shall meet and break our minds at large.

dialogues.speaker: Winchester
dialogues.line: Gloucester, we will meet, to thy cost, be sure; Thy heart-blood I will have for this day's work.

dialogues.speaker: Mayor
dialogues.line: I'll call for clubs, if you will not away. This Cardinal's more haughty than the devil.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Mayor, farewell. Thou dost but what thou mayst.

dialogues.speaker: Winchester
dialogues.line: Abominable Gloucester, guard thy head, For I intend to have it ere long.

dialogues.speaker: Mayor
dialogues.line: See the coast clear'd, and then we will depart. Good God, these nobles should such stomachs bear! I myself fight not once in forty year.

dialogues.speaker: Master Gunner
dialogues.line: Sirrah, thou know'st how Orleans is besieged, And how the English have the suburbs won.

dialogues.speaker: Boy
dialogues.line: Father, I know; and oft have shot at them, Howe'er unfortunate I miss'd my aim.

dialogues.speaker: Master Gunner
dialogues.line: But now thou shalt not. Be thou ruled by me. Chief master-gunner am I of this town; Something I must do to procure me grace. The Prince's espials have informed me How the English, in the suburbs close intrench'd, Wont, through a secret grate of iron bars In yonder tower, to overpeer the city, And thence discover how with most advantage They may vex us with shot or with assault. To intercept this inconvenience, A piece of ordnance 'gainst it I have placed And even these three days have I watch'd, If I could see them. Now do thou watch, for I can stay no longer. If thou spy'st any, run and bring me word; And thou shalt find me at the Governor's.

dialogues.speaker: Boy
dialogues.line: Father, I warrant you; take you no care; I'll never trouble you if I may spy them. Enter, on the turrets, Salisbury and Talbot, Sir William Glansdale, Sir Thomas Gargrave and others.

dialogues.speaker: Salisbury
dialogues.line: Talbot, my life, my joy, again return'd! How wert thou handled, being prisoner? Or by what means got'st thou to be releas'd? Discourse, I prithee, on this turret's top.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: The Duke of Bedford had a prisoner Call'd the brave Lord Ponton de Santrailles; For him was I exchanged and ransomed. But with a baser man of arms by far Once in contempt they would have barter'd me, Which I disdaining scorn'd, and craved death Rather than I would be so vile-esteem'd. In fine, redeem'd I was as I desired. But O, the treacherous Fastolf wounds my heart, Whom with my bare fists I would execute If I now had him brought into my power.

dialogues.speaker: Salisbury
dialogues.line: Yet tell'st thou not how thou wert entertain'd.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: With scoffs and scorns and contumelious taunts. In open market-place produced they me To be a public spectacle to all. Here, said they, is the terror of the French, The scarecrow that affrights our children so. Then broke I from the officers that led me, And with my nails digg'd stones out of the ground To hurl at the beholders of my shame. My grisly countenance made others fly; None durst come near for fear of sudden death. In iron walls they deem'd me not secure; So great fear of my name 'mongst them were spread That they supposed I could rend bars of steel And spurn in pieces posts of adamant. Wherefore a guard of chosen shot I had, That walk'd about me every minute while; And if I did but stir out of my bed, Ready they were to shoot me to the heart.

dialogues.speaker: Salisbury
dialogues.line: I grieve to hear what torments you endured, But we will be revenged sufficiently. Now it is supper-time in Orleans. Here, through this grate, I count each one And view the Frenchmen how they fortify. Let us look in; the sight will much delight thee. Sir Thomas Gargrave and Sir William Glansdale, Let me have your express opinions Where is best place to make our battery next.

dialogues.speaker: Gargrave
dialogues.line: I think, at the north gate, for there stand lords.

dialogues.speaker: Glansdale
dialogues.line: And I, here, at the bulwark of the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: For aught I see, this city must be famish'd, Or with light skirmishes enfeebled. Here they shoot, and Salisbury and Gargrave fall down.

dialogues.speaker: Salisbury
dialogues.line: O Lord, have mercy on us, wretched sinners!

dialogues.speaker: Gargrave
dialogues.line: O Lord, have mercy on me, woeful man!

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: What chance is this that suddenly hath cross'd us? Speak, Salisbury; at least, if thou canst speak! How far'st thou, mirror of all martial men? One of thy eyes and thy cheek's side struck off! Accursed tower, accursed fatal hand That hath contrived this woeful tragedy! In thirteen battles Salisbury o'ercame; Henry the Fifth he first train'd to the wars; Whilst any trump did sound, or drum struck up, His sword did ne'er leave striking in the field. Yet liv'st thou, Salisbury? Though thy speech doth fail, One eye thou hast to look to heaven for grace. The sun with one eye vieweth all the world. Heaven, be thou gracious to none alive, If Salisbury wants mercy at thy hands! Sir Thomas Gargrave, hast thou any life? Speak unto Talbot; nay, look up to him. Bear hence his body; I will help to bury it. Salisbury, cheer thy spirit with this comfort, Thou shalt not die whiles- He beckons with his hand and smiles on me, As who should say "When I am dead and gone, Remember to avenge me on the French." Plantagenet, I will; and, like thee, Nero, Play on the lute, beholding the towns burn. Wretched shall France be only in thy name. What stir is this? What tumult's in the heavens? Whence cometh this alarum and the noise?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: My lord, my lord, the French have gather'd head. The Dauphin, with one Joan la Pucelle join'd, A holy prophetess new risen up, Is come with a great power to raise the siege.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: Hear, hear how dying Salisbury doth groan; It irks his heart he cannot be revenged. Frenchmen, I'll be a Salisbury to you. Pucelle or puzel, dolphin or dogfish, Your hearts I'll stamp out with my horse's heels And make a quagmire of your mingled brains. Convey we Salisbury into his tent, And then we'll try what these dastard Frenchmen dare.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: Where is my strength, my valour, and my force? Our English troops retire, I cannot stay them. A woman clad in armour chaseth them. Here, here she comes. I'll have a bout with thee; Devil or devil's dam, I'll conjure thee. Blood will I draw on thee, thou art a witch, And straightway give thy soul to him thou serv'st.

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: Come, come, 'tis only I that must disgrace thee.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: Heavens, can you suffer hell so to prevail? My breast I'll burst with straining of my courage, And from my shoulders crack my arms asunder, But I will chastise this high-minded strumpet.

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: Talbot, farewell; thy hour is not yet come. I must go victual Orleans forthwith. O'ertake me, if thou canst. I scorn thy strength. Go, go, cheer up thy hungry-starved men; Help Salisbury to make his testament. This day is ours, as many more shall be.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: My thoughts are whirled like a potter's wheel; I know not where I am, nor what I do. A witch by fear, not force, like Hannibal, Drives back our troops and conquers as she lists. So bees with smoke and doves with noisome stench Are from their hives and houses driven away. They call'd us for our fierceness, English dogs; Now like to whelps we crying run away. Hark, countrymen, either renew the fight, Or tear the lions out of England's coat; Renounce your soil, give sheep in lions' stead. Sheep run not half so treacherous from the wolf, Or horse or oxen from the leopard, As you fly from your oft-subdued slaves. It will not be! Retire into your trenches. You all consented unto Salisbury's death, For none would strike a stroke in his revenge. Pucelle is enter'd into Orleans, In spite of us or aught that we could do. O, would I were to die with Salisbury! The shame hereof will make me hide my head.

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: Advance our waving colours on the walls; Rescued is Orleans from the English. Thus Joan la Pucelle hath perform'd her word.

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: Divinest creature, Astraea's daughter, How shall I honour thee for this success? Thy promises are like Adonis' gardens That one day bloom'd and fruitful were the next. France, triumph in thy glorious prophetess! Recover'd is the town of Orleans. More blessed hap did ne'er befall our state.

dialogues.speaker: Reignier
dialogues.line: Why ring not bells aloud throughout the town? Dauphin, command the citizens make bonfires And feast and banquet in the open streets To celebrate the joy that God hath given us. ALENÇON. All France will be replete with mirth and joy When they shall hear how we have play'd the men.

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: 'Tis Joan, not we, by whom the day is won; For which I will divide my crown with her, And all the priests and friars in my realm Shall in procession sing her endless praise. A statelier pyramis to her I'll rear Than Rhodope's of Memphis ever was; In memory of her when she is dead, Her ashes, in an urn more precious Than the rich-jewel'd coffer of Darius, Transported shall be at high festivals Before the kings and queens of France. No longer on Saint Denis will we cry, But Joan la Pucelle shall be France's saint. Come in, and let us banquet royally After this golden day of victory.

dialogues.speaker: Sergeant
dialogues.line: Sirs, take your places and be vigilant. If any noise or soldier you perceive Near to the walls, by some apparent sign Let us have knowledge at the court of guard.

dialogues.speaker: First Sentinel
dialogues.line: Sergeant, you shall. Thus are poor servitors, When others sleep upon their quiet beds, Constrain'd to watch in darkness, rain, and cold. Enter Talbot, Bedford, Burgundy, and forces, with scaling-ladders.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: Lord Regent, and redoubted Burgundy, By whose approach the regions of Artois, Walloon and Picardy are friends to us, This happy night the Frenchmen are secure, Having all day caroused and banqueted. Embrace we then this opportunity, As fitting best to quittance their deceit Contriv'd by art and baleful sorcery.

dialogues.speaker: Bedford
dialogues.line: Coward of France, how much he wrongs his fame, Despairing of his own arm's fortitude, To join with witches and the help of hell!

dialogues.speaker: Burgundy
dialogues.line: Traitors have never other company. But what's that Pucelle whom they term so pure?

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: A maid, they say.

dialogues.speaker: Bedford
dialogues.line: A maid! And be so martial!

dialogues.speaker: Burgundy
dialogues.line: Pray God she prove not masculine ere long, If underneath the standard of the French She carry armour as she hath begun.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: Well, let them practice and converse with spirits. God is our fortress, in whose conquering name Let us resolve to scale their flinty bulwarks.

dialogues.speaker: Bedford
dialogues.line: Ascend, brave Talbot; we will follow thee.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: Not all together. Better far, I guess, That we do make our entrance several ways, That if it chance the one of us do fail, The other yet may rise against their force.

dialogues.speaker: Bedford
dialogues.line: Agreed. I'll to yond corner.

dialogues.speaker: Burgundy
dialogues.line: And I to this.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: And here will Talbot mount, or make his grave. Now, Salisbury, for thee, and for the right Of English Henry, shall this night appear How much in duty I am bound to both.

dialogues.speaker: Sentinel
dialogues.line: Arm! Arm! The enemy doth make assault! The French leap over the walls in their shirts. Enter several ways the Bastard of Orleans, Alençon and Reignier, half ready and half unready. ALENÇON. How now, my lords? What, all unready so?

dialogues.speaker: Bastard
dialogues.line: Unready! Ay, and glad we 'scap'd so well.

dialogues.speaker: Reignier
dialogues.line: 'Twas time, I trow, to wake and leave our beds, Hearing alarums at our chamber-doors. ALENÇON. Of all exploits since first I follow'd arms Ne'er heard I of a warlike enterprise More venturous or desperate than this.

dialogues.speaker: Bastard
dialogues.line: I think this Talbot be a fiend of hell.

dialogues.speaker: Reignier
dialogues.line: If not of hell, the heavens, sure, favour him. ALENÇON. Here cometh Charles. I marvel how he sped.

dialogues.speaker: Bastard
dialogues.line: Tut, holy Joan was his defensive guard.

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: Is this thy cunning, thou deceitful dame? Didst thou at first, to flatter us withal, Make us partakers of a little gain, That now our loss might be ten times so much?

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: Wherefore is Charles impatient with his friend? At all times will you have my power alike? Sleeping or waking, must I still prevail, Or will you blame and lay the fault on me? Improvident soldiers, had your watch been good, This sudden mischief never could have fall'n.

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: Duke of Alençon, this was your default, That, being captain of the watch tonight, Did look no better to that weighty charge. ALENÇON. Had all your quarters been as safely kept As that whereof I had the government, We had not been thus shamefully surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Bastard
dialogues.line: Mine was secure.

dialogues.speaker: Reignier
dialogues.line: And so was mine, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: And for myself, most part of all this night, I was employ'd in passing to and fro About relieving of the sentinels. Then how or which way should they first break in?

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: Question, my lords, no further of the case, How or which way; 'tis sure they found some place But weakly guarded, where the breach was made. And now there rests no other shift but this: To gather our soldiers, scattered and dispersed, And lay new platforms to endamage them. Alarum. Enter an  English Soldier, crying "A Talbot! A Talbot!" They fly, leaving their clothes behind.

dialogues.speaker: Soldier
dialogues.line: I'll be so bold to take what they have left. The cry of "Talbot" serves me for a sword; For I have loaden me with many spoils, Using no other weapon but his name.

dialogues.speaker: Bedford
dialogues.line: The day begins to break, and night is fled, Whose pitchy mantle over-veil'd the earth. Here sound retreat and cease our hot pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: Bring forth the body of old Salisbury, And here advance it in the market-place, The middle centre of this cursed town. Dead March. Enter with the body of Salisbury. Now have I paid my vow unto his soul; For every drop of blood was drawn from him There hath at least five Frenchmen died tonight. And that hereafter ages may behold What ruin happen'd in revenge of him, Within their chiefest temple I'll erect A tomb, wherein his corpse shall be interr'd; Upon the which, that everyone may read, Shall be engraved the sack of Orleans, The treacherous manner of his mournful death And what a terror he had been to France. But, lords, in all our bloody massacre, I muse we met not with the Dauphin's grace, His new-come champion, virtuous Joan of Arc, Nor any of his false confederates.

dialogues.speaker: Bedford
dialogues.line: 'Tis thought, Lord Talbot, when the fight began, Rous'd on the sudden from their drowsy beds, They did amongst the troops of armed men Leap o'er the walls for refuge in the field.

dialogues.speaker: Burgundy
dialogues.line: Myself, as far as I could well discern For smoke and dusky vapors of the night, Am sure I scared the Dauphin and his trull, When arm in arm they both came swiftly running, Like to a pair of loving turtle-doves That could not live asunder day or night. After that things are set in order here, We'll follow them with all the power we have.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: All hail, my lords! Which of this princely train Call ye the warlike Talbot, for his acts So much applauded through the realm of France?

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: Here is the Talbot. Who would speak with him?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: The virtuous lady, Countess of Auvergne, With modesty admiring thy renown, By me entreats, great lord, thou wouldst vouchsafe To visit her poor castle where she lies, That she may boast she hath beheld the man Whose glory fills the world with loud report.

dialogues.speaker: Burgundy
dialogues.line: Is it even so? Nay, then I see our wars Will turn unto a peaceful comic sport, When ladies crave to be encounter'd with. You may not, my lord, despise her gentle suit.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: Ne'er trust me then; for when a world of men Could not prevail with all their oratory, Yet hath a woman's kindness over-ruled. And therefore tell her I return great thanks, And in submission will attend on her. Will not your honours bear me company?

dialogues.speaker: Bedford
dialogues.line: No, truly, it is more than manners will; And I have heard it said, unbidden guests Are often welcomest when they are gone.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: Well then, alone, since there's no remedy, I mean to prove this lady's courtesy. Come hither, Captain.  You perceive my mind?

dialogues.speaker: Captain
dialogues.line: I do, my lord, and mean accordingly.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Porter, remember what I gave in charge; And when you have done so, bring the keys to me.

dialogues.speaker: Porter
dialogues.line: Madam, I will.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: The plot is laid. If all things fall out right, I shall as famous be by this exploit As Scythian Tomyris by Cyrus' death. Great is the rumour of this dreadful knight, And his achievements of no less account. Fain would mine eyes be witness with mine ears, To give their censure of these rare reports.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Madam, according as your ladyship desired, By message craved, so is Lord Talbot come.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: And he is welcome. What, is this the man?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Madam, it is.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Is this the scourge of France? Is this the Talbot, so much fear'd abroad That with his name the mothers still their babes? I see report is fabulous and false. I thought I should have seen some Hercules, A second Hector, for his grim aspect, And large proportion of his strong-knit limbs. Alas, this is a child, a silly dwarf! It cannot be this weak and writhled shrimp Should strike such terror to his enemies.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: Madam, I have been bold to trouble you; But since your ladyship is not at leisure, I'll sort some other time to visit you.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: What means he now? Go ask him whither he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Stay, my Lord Talbot, for my lady craves To know the cause of your abrupt departure.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: Marry, for that she's in a wrong belief, I go to certify her Talbot's here.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: If thou be he, then art thou prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: Prisoner! To whom?

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: To me, blood-thirsty lord; And for that cause I train'd thee to my house. Long time thy shadow hath been thrall to me, For in my gallery thy picture hangs. But now the substance shall endure the like, And I will chain these legs and arms of thine, That hast by tyranny these many years Wasted our country, slain our citizens, And sent our sons and husbands captivate.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: Ha, ha, ha!

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Laughest thou, wretch? Thy mirth shall turn to moan.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: I laugh to see your ladyship so fond To think that you have aught but Talbot's shadow Whereon to practice your severity.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Why, art not thou the man?

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: I am indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Then have I substance too.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: No, no, I am but shadow of myself. You are deceived, my substance is not here; For what you see is but the smallest part And least proportion of humanity. I tell you, madam, were the whole frame here, It is of such a spacious lofty pitch Your roof were not sufficient to contain 't.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: This is a riddling merchant for the nonce; He will be here, and yet he is not here. How can these contrarieties agree?

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: That will I show you presently. Winds his horn. Drums strike up; a peal of ordnance. Enter Soldiers. How say you, madam? Are you now persuaded That Talbot is but shadow of himself? These are his substance, sinews, arms and strength, With which he yoketh your rebellious necks, Razeth your cities and subverts your towns, And in a moment makes them desolate.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: Victorious Talbot, pardon my abuse. I find thou art no less than fame hath bruited, And more than may be gather'd by thy shape. Let my presumption not provoke thy wrath, For I am sorry that with reverence I did not entertain thee as thou art.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: Be not dismay'd, fair lady, nor misconster The mind of Talbot, as you did mistake The outward composition of his body. What you have done hath not offended me; Nor other satisfaction do I crave But only, with your patience, that we may Taste of your wine and see what cates you have, For soldiers' stomachs always serve them well.

dialogues.speaker: Countess
dialogues.line: With all my heart, and think me honoured To feast so great a warrior in my house.

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: Great lords and gentlemen, what means this silence? Dare no man answer in a case of truth?

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Within the Temple Hall we were too loud; The garden here is more convenient.

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: Then say at once if I maintain'd the truth; Or else was wrangling Somerset in th' error?

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Faith, I have been a truant in the law And never yet could frame my will to it; And therefore frame the law unto my will.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: Judge you, my Lord of Warwick, then, between us.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Between two hawks, which flies the higher pitch; Between two dogs, which hath the deeper mouth; Between two blades, which bears the better temper; Between two horses, which doth bear him best; Between two girls, which hath the merriest eye; I have perhaps some shallow spirit of judgement; But in these nice sharp quillets of the law, Good faith, I am no wiser than a daw.

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: Tut, tut, here is a mannerly forbearance! The truth appears so naked on my side That any purblind eye may find it out.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: And on my side it is so well apparell'd, So clear, so shining and so evident, That it will glimmer through a blind man's eye.

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: Since you are tongue-tied and so loath to speak, In dumb significants proclaim your thoughts: Let him that is a true-born gentleman And stands upon the honour of his birth, If he suppose that I have pleaded truth, From off this brier pluck a white rose with me.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: Let him that is no coward nor no flatterer, But dare maintain the party of the truth, Pluck a red rose from off this thorn with me.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: I love no colours, and without all colour Of base insinuating flattery I pluck this white rose with Plantagenet.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: I pluck this red rose with young Somerset, And say withal I think he held the right.

dialogues.speaker: Vernon
dialogues.line: Stay, lords and gentlemen, and pluck no more Till you conclude that he upon whose side The fewest roses are cropp'd from the tree Shall yield the other in the right opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: Good Master Vernon, it is well objected: If I have fewest, I subscribe in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: And I.

dialogues.speaker: Vernon
dialogues.line: Then for the truth and plainness of the case, I pluck this pale and maiden blossom here, Giving my verdict on the white rose side.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: Prick not your finger as you pluck it off, Lest, bleeding, you do paint the white rose red, And fall on my side so against your will.

dialogues.speaker: Vernon
dialogues.line: If I, my lord, for my opinion bleed, Opinion shall be surgeon to my hurt And keep me on the side where still I am.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: Well, well, come on, who else?

dialogues.speaker: Lawyer
dialogues.line: Unless my study and my books be false, The argument you held was wrong in law; In sign whereof I pluck a white rose too.

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: Now, Somerset, where is your argument?

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: Here in my scabbard, meditating that Shall dye your white rose in a bloody red.

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: Meantime your cheeks do counterfeit our roses; For pale they look with fear, as witnessing The truth on our side.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: No, Plantagenet, 'Tis not for fear but anger that thy cheeks Blush for pure shame to counterfeit our roses, And yet thy tongue will not confess thy error.

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: Hath not thy rose a canker, Somerset?

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: Hath not thy rose a thorn, Plantagenet?

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: Ay, sharp and piercing, to maintain his truth; Whiles thy consuming canker eats his falsehood.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: Well, I'll find friends to wear my bleeding roses, That shall maintain what I have said is true, Where false Plantagenet dare not be seen.

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: Now, by this maiden blossom in my hand, I scorn thee and thy fashion, peevish boy.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Turn not thy scorns this way, Plantagenet.

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: Proud Pole, I will, and scorn both him and thee.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: I'll turn my part thereof into thy throat.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: Away, away, good William de la Pole! We grace the yeoman by conversing with him.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Now, by God's will, thou wrong'st him, Somerset; His grandfather was Lionel Duke of Clarence, Third son to the third Edward King of England. Spring crestless yeomen from so deep a root?

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: He bears him on the place's privilege, Or durst not for his craven heart, say thus.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: By Him that made me, I'll maintain my words On any plot of ground in Christendom. Was not thy father, Richard Earl of Cambridge, For treason executed in our late king's days? And, by his treason, stand'st not thou attainted, Corrupted, and exempt from ancient gentry? His trespass yet lives guilty in thy blood; And, till thou be restored, thou art a yeoman.

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: My father was attached, not attainted, Condemn'd to die for treason, but no traitor; And that I'll prove on better men than Somerset, Were growing time once ripen'd to my will. For your partaker Pole and you yourself, I'll note you in my book of memory, To scourge you for this apprehension. Look to it well, and say you are well warn'd.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: Ah, thou shalt find us ready for thee still; And know us by these colours for thy foes, For these my friends in spite of thee shall wear.

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: And, by my soul, this pale and angry rose, As cognizance of my blood-drinking hate, Will I for ever and my faction wear, Until it wither with me to my grave, Or flourish to the height of my degree.

dialogues.speaker: Suffolk
dialogues.line: Go forward, and be chok'd with thy ambition! And so farewell until I meet thee next.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: Have with thee, Pole. Farewell, ambitious Richard.

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: How I am braved and must perforce endure it!

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: This blot that they object against your house Shall be wiped out in the next parliament Call'd for the truce of Winchester and Gloucester; And if thou be not then created York, I will not live to be accounted Warwick. Meantime, in signal of my love to thee, Against proud Somerset and William Pole, Will I upon thy party wear this rose. And here I prophesy: this brawl today, Grown to this faction in the Temple Garden, Shall send between the Red Rose and the White A thousand souls to death and deadly night.

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: Good Master Vernon, I am bound to you, That you on my behalf would pluck a flower.

dialogues.speaker: Vernon
dialogues.line: In your behalf still will I wear the same.

dialogues.speaker: Lawyer
dialogues.line: And so will I.

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: Thanks, gentlemen. Come, let us four to dinner. I dare say This quarrel will drink blood another day.

dialogues.speaker: Mortimer
dialogues.line: Kind keepers of my weak decaying age, Let dying Mortimer here rest himself. Even like a man new haled from the rack, So fare my limbs with long imprisonment; And these gray locks, the pursuivants of death, Nestor-like aged in an age of care, Argue the end of Edmund Mortimer. These eyes, like lamps whose wasting oil is spent, Wax dim, as drawing to their exigent; Weak shoulders, overborne with burdening grief, And pithless arms, like to a wither'd vine That droops his sapless branches to the ground. Yet are these feet, whose strengthless stay is numb, Unable to support this lump of clay, Swift-winged with desire to get a grave, As witting I no other comfort have. But tell me, keeper, will my nephew come?

dialogues.speaker: First Jailer
dialogues.line: Richard Plantagenet, my lord, will come. We sent unto the Temple, unto his chamber, And answer was return'd that he will come.

dialogues.speaker: Mortimer
dialogues.line: Enough. My soul shall then be satisfied. Poor gentleman, his wrong doth equal mine. Since Henry Monmouth first began to reign, Before whose glory I was great in arms, This loathsome sequestration have I had; And even since then hath Richard been obscured, Deprived of honour and inheritance. But now the arbitrator of despairs, Just Death, kind umpire of men's miseries, With sweet enlargement doth dismiss me hence. I would his troubles likewise were expired, That so he might recover what was lost.

dialogues.speaker: First Jailer
dialogues.line: My lord, your loving nephew now is come.

dialogues.speaker: Mortimer
dialogues.line: Richard Plantagenet, my friend, is he come?

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: Ay, noble uncle, thus ignobly used, Your nephew, late despised Richard, comes.

dialogues.speaker: Mortimer
dialogues.line: Direct mine arms I may embrace his neck And in his bosom spend my latter gasp. O, tell me when my lips do touch his cheeks, That I may kindly give one fainting kiss. And now declare, sweet stem from York's great stock, Why didst thou say of late thou wert despised?

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: First, lean thine aged back against mine arm, And, in that ease, I'll tell thee my disease. This day, in argument upon a case, Some words there grew 'twixt Somerset and me; Among which terms he used his lavish tongue And did upbraid me with my father's death; Which obloquy set bars before my tongue, Else with the like I had requited him. Therefore, good uncle, for my father's sake, In honour of a true Plantagenet, And for alliance' sake, declare the cause My father, Earl of Cambridge, lost his head.

dialogues.speaker: Mortimer
dialogues.line: That cause, fair nephew, that imprison'd me And hath detain'd me all my flowering youth Was cursed instrument of his decease.

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: Discover more at large what cause that was, For I am ignorant and cannot guess.

dialogues.speaker: Mortimer
dialogues.line: I will, if that my fading breath permit And death approach not ere my tale be done. Henry the Fourth, grandfather to this king, Deposed his nephew Richard, Edward's son, The first-begotten and the lawful heir Of Edward king, the third of that descent; During whose reign the Percies of the north, Finding his usurpation most unjust, Endeavour'd my advancement to the throne. The reason moved these warlike lords to this Was, for that-young King Richard thus removed, Leaving no heir begotten of his body- I was the next by birth and parentage; For by my mother I derived am From Lionel Duke of Clarence, third son To King Edward the Third; whereas he From John of Gaunt doth bring his pedigree, Being but fourth of that heroic line. But mark: as in this haughty great attempt They labored to plant the rightful heir, I lost my liberty and they their lives. Long after this, when Henry the Fifth, Succeeding his father Bolingbroke, did reign, Thy father, Earl of Cambridge then, derived From famous Edmund Langley, Duke of York, Marrying my sister that thy mother was, Again, in pity of my hard distress. Levied an army, weening to redeem And have install'd me in the diadem. But, as the rest, so fell that noble earl And was beheaded. Thus the Mortimers, In whom the title rested, were suppress'd.

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: Of which, my lord, your honour is the last.

dialogues.speaker: Mortimer
dialogues.line: True; and thou seest that I no issue have, And that my fainting words do warrant death. Thou art my heir; the rest I wish thee gather. But yet be wary in thy studious care.

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: Thy grave admonishments prevail with me. But yet methinks, my father's execution Was nothing less than bloody tyranny.

dialogues.speaker: Mortimer
dialogues.line: With silence, nephew, be thou politic; Strong-fixed is the house of Lancaster, And like a mountain, not to be removed. But now thy uncle is removing hence, As princes do their courts when they are cloy'd With long continuance in a settled place.

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: O uncle, would some part of my young years Might but redeem the passage of your age!

dialogues.speaker: Mortimer
dialogues.line: Thou dost then wrong me, as that slaughterer doth Which giveth many wounds when one will kill. Mourn not, except thou sorrow for my good; Only give order for my funeral. And so farewell, and fair be all thy hopes, And prosperous be thy life in peace and war!

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: And peace, no war, befall thy parting soul! In prison hast thou spent a pilgrimage, And like a hermit overpass'd thy days. Well, I will lock his counsel in my breast; And what I do imagine, let that rest. Keepers, convey him hence; and I myself Will see his burial better than his life. Here dies the dusky torch of Mortimer, Choked with ambition of the meaner sort. And for those wrongs, those bitter injuries, Which Somerset hath offer'd to my house, I doubt not but with honour to redress; And therefore haste I to the Parliament, Either to be restored to my blood, Or make mine ill th' advantage of my good.

dialogues.speaker: Winchester
dialogues.line: Com'st thou with deep premeditated lines, With written pamphlets studiously devised, Humphrey of Gloucester? If thou canst accuse Or aught intend'st to lay unto my charge, Do it without invention, suddenly; As I with sudden and extemporal speech Purpose to answer what thou canst object.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Presumptuous priest, this place commands my patience, Or thou shouldst find thou hast dishonour'd me. Think not, although in writing I preferr'd The manner of thy vile outrageous crimes, That therefore I have forged, or am not able Verbatim to rehearse the method of my pen. No, prelate; such is thy audacious wickedness, Thy lewd, pestiferous, and dissentious pranks, As very infants prattle of thy pride. Thou art a most pernicious usurer, Froward by nature, enemy to peace; Lascivious, wanton, more than well beseems A man of thy profession and degree; And for thy treachery, what's more manifest, In that thou laid'st a trap to take my life, As well at London Bridge as at the Tower? Beside, I fear me, if thy thoughts are sifted, The King, thy sovereign, is not quite exempt From envious malice of thy swelling heart.

dialogues.speaker: Winchester
dialogues.line: Gloucester, I do defy thee. Lords, vouchsafe To give me hearing what I shall reply. If I were covetous, ambitious, or perverse, As he will have me, how am I so poor? Or how haps it I seek not to advance Or raise myself, but keep my wonted calling? And for dissension, who preferreth peace More than I do, except I be provoked? No, my good lords, it is not that offends; It is not that that hath incensed the Duke. It is because no one should sway but he, No one but he should be about the King; And that engenders thunder in his breast And makes him roar these accusations forth. But he shall know I am as good-

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: As good! Thou bastard of my grandfather!

dialogues.speaker: Winchester
dialogues.line: Ay, lordly sir; for what are you, I pray, But one imperious in another's throne?

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Am I not Protector, saucy priest?

dialogues.speaker: Winchester
dialogues.line: And am not I a prelate of the church?

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Yes, as an outlaw in a castle keeps, And useth it to patronage his theft.

dialogues.speaker: Winchester
dialogues.line: Unreverent Gloucester!

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Thou art reverend Touching thy spiritual function, not thy life.

dialogues.speaker: Winchester
dialogues.line: Rome shall remedy this.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Roam thither, then.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: My lord, it were your duty to forbear.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: Ay, so the bishop be not overborne. Methinks my lord should be religious, And know the office that belongs to such.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Methinks his lordship should be humbler; It fitteth not a prelate so to plead.

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: Yes, when his holy state is touch'd so near.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: State holy or unhallow'd, what of that? Is not his Grace Protector to the King?

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: Plantagenet, I see, must hold his tongue, Lest it be said, "Speak, sirrah, when you should; Must your bold verdict enter talk with lords?" Else would I have a fling at Winchester.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Uncles of Gloucester and of Winchester, The special watchmen of our English weal, I would prevail, if prayers might prevail, To join your hearts in love and amity. O, what a scandal is it to our crown That two such noble peers as ye should jar! Believe me, lords, my tender years can tell Civil dissension is a viperous worm That gnaws the bowels of the commonwealth. What tumult's this?

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: An uproar, I dare warrant, Begun through malice of the Bishop's men.

dialogues.speaker: Mayor
dialogues.line: O, my good lords, and virtuous Henry, Pity the city of London, pity us! The Bishop and the Duke of Gloucester's men, Forbidden late to carry any weapon, Have fill'd their pockets full of pebble stones And, banding themselves in contrary parts, Do pelt so fast at one another's pate That many have their giddy brains knock'd out; Our windows are broke down in every street, And we for fear compell'd to shut our shops.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: We charge you, on allegiance to ourself, To hold your slaughtering hands and keep the peace. Pray, uncle Gloucester, mitigate this strife.

dialogues.speaker: First Servingman
dialogues.line: Nay, if we be forbidden stones, we'll fall to it with our teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Second Servingman
dialogues.line: Do what ye dare, we are as resolute.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: You of my household, leave this peevish broil, And set this unaccustom'd fight aside.

dialogues.speaker: Third Servingman
dialogues.line: My lord, we know your Grace to be a man Just and upright, and, for your royal birth, Inferior to none but to his Majesty; And ere that we will suffer such a prince, So kind a father of the commonweal, To be disgraced by an inkhorn mate, We and our wives and children all will fight And have our bodies slaughter'd by thy foes.

dialogues.speaker: First Servingman
dialogues.line: Ay, and the very parings of our nails Shall pitch a field when we are dead.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Stay, stay, I say! And if you love me, as you say you do, Let me persuade you to forbear awhile.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: O, how this discord doth afflict my soul! Can you, my Lord of Winchester, behold My sighs and tears, and will not once relent? Who should be pitiful, if you be not? Or who should study to prefer a peace If holy churchmen take delight in broils?

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Yield, my Lord Protector; yield, Winchester; Except you mean with obstinate repulse To slay your sovereign and destroy the realm. You see what mischief and what murder too, Hath been enacted through your enmity; Then be at peace, except ye thirst for blood.

dialogues.speaker: Winchester
dialogues.line: He shall submit, or I will never yield.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Compassion on the King commands me stoop, Or I would see his heart out, ere the priest Should ever get that privilege of me.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Behold, my Lord of Winchester, the Duke Hath banish'd moody discontented fury, As by his smoothed brows it doth appear. Why look you still so stern and tragical?

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Here, Winchester, I offer thee my hand.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Fie, uncle Beaufort! I have heard you preach That malice was a great and grievous sin; And will not you maintain the thing you teach, But prove a chief offender in the same?

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Sweet King! The bishop hath a kindly gird. For shame, my Lord of Winchester, relent! What, shall a child instruct you what to do?

dialogues.speaker: Winchester
dialogues.line: Well, Duke of Gloucester, I will yield to thee; Love for thy love and hand for hand I give.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Ay, but, I fear me, with a hollow heart.- See here, my friends and loving countrymen, This token serveth for a flag of truce Betwixt ourselves and all our followers, So help me God, as I dissemble not!

dialogues.speaker: Winchester
dialogues.line: So help me God, as I intend it not!

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: O loving uncle, kind Duke of Gloucester, How joyful am I made by this contract! Away, my masters, trouble us no more, But join in friendship, as your lords have done.

dialogues.speaker: First Servingman
dialogues.line: Content. I'll to the surgeon's.

dialogues.speaker: Second Servingman
dialogues.line: And so will I.

dialogues.speaker: Third Servingman
dialogues.line: And I will see what physic the tavern affords.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Accept this scroll, most gracious sovereign, Which in the right of Richard Plantagenet We do exhibit to your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Well urged, my Lord of Warwick. For, sweet prince, An if your Grace mark every circumstance, You have great reason to do Richard right, Especially for those occasions At Eltham Place I told your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: And those occasions, uncle, were of force; Therefore, my loving lords, our pleasure is That Richard be restored to his blood.

dialogues.speaker: Warwick
dialogues.line: Let Richard be restored to his blood; So shall his father's wrongs be recompensed.

dialogues.speaker: Winchester
dialogues.line: As will the rest, so willeth Winchester.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: If Richard will be true, not that alone But all the whole inheritance I give That doth belong unto the house of York, From whence you spring by lineal descent.

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: Thy humble servant vows obedience And humble service till the point of death.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: Stoop then and set your knee against my foot; And in reguerdon of that duty done I girt thee with the valiant sword of York. Rise, Richard, like a true Plantagenet, And rise created princely Duke of York.

dialogues.speaker: Plantagenet
dialogues.line: And so thrive Richard as thy foes may fall! And as my duty springs, so perish they That grudge one thought against your Majesty!

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: Welcome, high prince, the mighty Duke of York!

dialogues.speaker: Somerset
dialogues.line: Perish, base prince, ignoble Duke of York!

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Now will it best avail your Majesty To cross the seas and to be crown'd in France. The presence of a king engenders love Amongst his subjects and his loyal friends, As it disanimates his enemies.

dialogues.speaker: King Henry
dialogues.line: When Gloucester says the word, King Henry goes; For friendly counsel cuts off many foes.

dialogues.speaker: Gloucester
dialogues.line: Your ships already are in readiness.

dialogues.speaker: Exeter
dialogues.line: Ay, we may march in England or in France, Not seeing what is likely to ensue. This late dissension grown betwixt the peers Burns under feigned ashes of forged love, And will at last break out into a flame; As festered members rot but by degree Till bones and flesh and sinews fall away, So will this base and envious discord breed. And now I fear that fatal prophecy Which in the time of Henry named the Fifth Was in the mouth of every sucking babe: That Henry born at Monmouth should win all, And Henry born at Windsor lose all, Which is so plain that Exeter doth wish His days may finish ere that hapless time.

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: These are the city gates, the gates of Rouen, Through which our policy must make a breach. Take heed, be wary how you place your words; Talk like the vulgar sort of market men That come to gather money for their corn. If we have entrance, as I hope we shall, And that we find the slothful watch but weak, I'll by a sign give notice to our friends, That Charles the Dauphin may encounter them.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: Our sacks shall be a mean to sack the city, And we be lords and rulers over Rouen; Therefore we'll knock.

dialogues.speaker: Watch
dialogues.line: _Qui est la?_

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: _Paysans, la pauvres gens de France:_ Poor market folks that come to sell their corn.

dialogues.speaker: Watch
dialogues.line: Enter, go in; the market bell is rung.

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: Now, Rouen, I'll shake thy bulwarks to the ground. Enter Charles, the Bastard of Orleans, Alençon, Reignier and forces.

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: Saint Denis bless this happy stratagem, And once again we'll sleep secure in Rouen.

dialogues.speaker: Bastard
dialogues.line: Here enter'd Pucelle and her practisants; Now she is there, how will she specify Here is the best and safest passage in?

dialogues.speaker: Reignier
dialogues.line: By thrusting out a torch from yonder tower, Which, once discern'd, shows that her meaning is: No way to that, for weakness, which she enter'd.

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: Behold, this is the happy wedding torch That joineth Rouen unto her countrymen, But burning fatal to the Talbonites.

dialogues.speaker: Bastard
dialogues.line: See, noble Charles, the beacon of our friend; The burning torch, in yonder turret stands.

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: Now shine it like a comet of revenge, A prophet to the fall of all our foes!

dialogues.speaker: Reignier
dialogues.line: Defer no time, delays have dangerous ends; Enter and cry, "The Dauphin!" presently, And then do execution on the watch. An alarum. Enter Talbot in an excursion.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: France, thou shalt rue this treason with thy tears, If Talbot but survive thy treachery. Pucelle, that witch, that damned sorceress, Hath wrought this hellish mischief unawares, That hardly we escaped the pride of France. An alarum. Excursions. Bedford, brought in sick in a chair. Enter Talbot and Burgundy without: within, La Pucelle, Charles, Bastard, Alençon, and Reignier on the walls.

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: Good morrow, gallants! Want ye corn for bread? I think the Duke of Burgundy will fast Before he'll buy again at such a rate. 'Twas full of darnel. Do you like the taste?

dialogues.speaker: Burgundy
dialogues.line: Scoff on, vile fiend and shameless courtezan! I trust ere long to choke thee with thine own, And make thee curse the harvest of that corn.

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: Your Grace may starve, perhaps, before that time.

dialogues.speaker: Bedford
dialogues.line: O, let no words, but deeds, revenge this treason!

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: What will you do, good graybeard? Break a lance And run a tilt at Death within a chair?

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: Foul fiend of France and hag of all despite, Encompass'd with thy lustful paramours, Becomes it thee to taunt his valiant age And twit with cowardice a man half dead? Damsel, I'll have a bout with you again, Or else let Talbot perish with this shame.

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: Are ye so hot? Yet, Pucelle, hold thy peace; If Talbot do but thunder, rain will follow. God speed the Parliament! Who shall be the Speaker?

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: Dare ye come forth and meet us in the field?

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: Belike your lordship takes us then for fools, To try if that our own be ours or no.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: I speak not to that railing Hecate, But unto thee, Alençon, and the rest; Will ye, like soldiers, come and fight it out? ALENÇON. Seignieur, no.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: Seignieur, hang! Base muleteers of France! Like peasant foot-boys do they keep the walls, And dare not take up arms like gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: Away, captains! Let's get us from the walls, For Talbot means no goodness by his looks. Goodbye, my lord; we came but to tell you That we are here.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: And there will we be too, ere it be long, Or else reproach be Talbot's greatest fame! Vow, Burgundy, by honour of thy house, Prick'd on by public wrongs sustain'd in France, Either to get the town again or die. And I, as sure as English Henry lives, And as his father here was conqueror, As sure as in this late-betrayed town Great Coeur-de-lion's heart was buried, So sure I swear to get the town or die.

dialogues.speaker: Burgundy
dialogues.line: My vows are equal partners with thy vows.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: But, ere we go, regard this dying prince, The valiant Duke of Bedford. Come, my lord, We will bestow you in some better place, Fitter for sickness and for crazy age.

dialogues.speaker: Bedford
dialogues.line: Lord Talbot, do not so dishonour me. Here will I sit before the walls of Rouen, And will be partner of your weal or woe.

dialogues.speaker: Burgundy
dialogues.line: Courageous Bedford, let us now persuade you.

dialogues.speaker: Bedford
dialogues.line: Not to be gone from hence; for once I read That stout Pendragon in his litter sick Came to the field and vanquished his foes. Methinks I should revive the soldiers' hearts, Because I ever found them as myself.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: Undaunted spirit in a dying breast! Then be it so. Heavens keep old Bedford safe! And now no more ado, brave Burgundy, But gather we our forces out of hand And set upon our boasting enemy. An alarum. Excursions. Enter Sir John Fastolf and a Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Captain
dialogues.line: Whither away, Sir John Fastolf, in such haste?

dialogues.speaker: Fastolf
dialogues.line: Whither away? To save myself by flight. We are like to have the overthrow again.

dialogues.speaker: Captain
dialogues.line: What! Will you fly, and leave Lord Talbot?

dialogues.speaker: Fastolf
dialogues.line: Ay, All the Talbots in the world, to save my life.

dialogues.speaker: Captain
dialogues.line: Cowardly knight, ill fortune follow thee! Retreat. Excursions. La Pucelle, Alençon and Charles fly.

dialogues.speaker: Bedford
dialogues.line: Now, quiet soul, depart when heaven please, For I have seen our enemies' overthrow. What is the trust or strength of foolish man? They that of late were daring with their scoffs Are glad and fain by flight to save themselves. An alarum. Enter Talbot, Burgundy and the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: Lost, and recover'd in a day again! This is a double honour, Burgundy. Yet heavens have glory for this victory!

dialogues.speaker: Burgundy
dialogues.line: Warlike and martial Talbot, Burgundy Enshrines thee in his heart, and there erects Thy noble deeds as valour's monuments.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: Thanks, gentle Duke. But where is Pucelle now? I think her old familiar is asleep. Now where's the Bastard's braves, and Charles his gleeks? What, all amort? Rouen hangs her head for grief That such a valiant company are fled. Now will we take some order in the town, Placing therein some expert officers, And then depart to Paris to the King, For there young Henry with his nobles lie.

dialogues.speaker: Burgundy
dialogues.line: What wills Lord Talbot pleaseth Burgundy.

dialogues.speaker: Talbot
dialogues.line: But yet, before we go, let's not forget The noble Duke of Bedford late deceased, But see his exequies fulfill'd in Rouen. A braver soldier never couched lance, A gentler heart did never sway in court; But kings and mightiest potentates must die, For that's the end of human misery.

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: Dismay not, princes, at this accident, Nor grieve that Rouen is so recovered. Care is no cure, but rather corrosive, For things that are not to be remedied. Let frantic Talbot triumph for a while And like a peacock sweep along his tail; We'll pull his plumes and take away his train, If Dauphin and the rest will be but ruled.

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: We have been guided by thee hitherto, And of thy cunning had no diffidence. One sudden foil shall never breed distrust

dialogues.speaker: Bastard
dialogues.line: Search out thy wit for secret policies, And we will make thee famous through the world. ALENÇON. We'll set thy statue in some holy place, And have thee reverenced like a blessed saint. Employ thee then, sweet virgin, for our good.

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: Then thus it must be; this doth Joan devise: By fair persuasions mix'd with sugar'd words We will entice the Duke of Burgundy To leave the Talbot and to follow us.

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: Ay, marry, sweeting, if we could do that, France were no place for Henry's warriors; Nor should that nation boast it so with us, But be extirped from our provinces. ALENÇON. For ever should they be expulsed from France, And not have title of an earldom here.

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: Your honours shall perceive how I will work To bring this matter to the wished end. Hark! By the sound of drum you may perceive Their powers are marching unto Paris-ward. There goes the Talbot, with his colours spread, And all the troops of English after him. Now in the rearward comes the Duke and his. Fortune in favour makes him lag behind. Summon a parley; we will talk with him.

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: A parley with the Duke of Burgundy!

dialogues.speaker: Burgundy
dialogues.line: Who craves a parley with the Burgundy?

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: The princely Charles of France, thy countryman.

dialogues.speaker: Burgundy
dialogues.line: What say'st thou, Charles? for I am marching hence.

dialogues.speaker: Charles
dialogues.line: Speak, Pucelle, and enchant him with thy words.

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
dialogues.line: Brave Burgundy, undoubted hope of France, Stay, let thy humble handmaid speak to thee.

dialogues.speaker: Burgundy
dialogues.line: Speak on, but be not over-tedious.

dialogues.speaker: Pucelle
